comments.raw_text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:5.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/5.0.1
Build ID: 20110707182747

Steps to reproduce:

Tried to edit or create a new post on WordPress 3.2.1 with a new profile on Firefox 5.01, with graphics acceleration enabled in Options.



Actual results:

The editor is very slow with a noticeable delay between characters entered. Deleting with backspace is even slower with about 10 or more backspace keypresses enqueued. Windows Taks Manager shows CPU about 2-3% when focus is on rich text editor, goes up to 10% when writing, and 20% when deleting with backspace.

When turning graphcis acceleration off, the rich text editor works as expected without delays.


Expected results:

Smooth text editing.
comments.creator: bugzilla@mozillalinks.org
comments.text:

Steps to reproduce:

Tried to edit or create a new post on WordPress 3.2.1 with a new profile on Firefox 5.01, with graphics acceleration enabled in Options.



Actual results:

The editor is very slow with a noticeable delay between characters entered. Deleting with backspace is even slower with about 10 or more backspace keypresses enqueued. Windows Taks Manager shows CPU about 2-3% when focus is on rich text editor, goes up to 10% when writing, and 20% when deleting with backspace.

When turning graphcis acceleration off, the rich text editor works as expected without delays.

comments.author: ajuma.bugzilla@alijuma.com
comments.text:
From about:support:

> Vendor ID
> 8086
>
> Device ID
> 0046

This integrated graphics card is often accompanied by a discrete graphics card (e.g. bug 667437). So this sounds like it might be a dual-GPU blacklisting issue (bug 628129). 

To confirm this, it would be helpful to know what kind of machine the user has.
comments.raw_text:
From about:support:

> Vendor ID
> 8086
>
> Device ID
> 0046

This integrated graphics card is often accompanied by a discrete graphics card (e.g. bug 667437). So this sounds like it might be a dual-GPU blacklisting issue (bug 628129). 

To confirm this, it would be helpful to know what kind of machine the user has.

comments.creator: bugzilla@mozillalinks.org
comments.raw_text: It is an HP Probook 4320s laptop. Core i3 @2.13GHz, Win7 SP1 64-bit, 4GB of RAM. http://h10010.www1.hp.com/wwpc/au/en/sm/WF06a/321957-321957-64295-3955552-3955552-4145545.html
comments.text: It is an HP Probook 4320s laptop. Core i3 @2.13GHz, Win7 SP1 64-bit, 4GB of RAM. http://h10010.www1.hp.com/wwpc/au/en/sm/WF06a/321957-321957-64295-3955552-3955552-4145545.html

comments.raw_text:
Some (but not all) HP 4320s laptops do indeed have a dual-GPU. For example:
http://h20195.www2.hp.com/V2/GetDocument.aspx?docname=4AA0-7696EEE&doctype=data%20sheet&doclang=EN_GB&searchquery=Laptops/Tablets/Netbooks/HP%20ProBook%204320s%20Notebook%20PC/WT153EA

comments.text:
Today I found out this bug appears fixed in the new Firefox 17.0 (official release).
Text typing and editing was smooth with Hardware acceleration turned on (or off). Same machine same wp install.

Appreas to be fixed.
